Award.AwardTitle: Constraints on the evolution of chromosome dosage compensation: a test in butterflies and moths
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research addresses the question of how genes evolve when individuals have different numbers of copies of each gene. In many species, the sex of the individual is determined by how many copies of the sex-determining chromosomes one has. In humans, females have two copies of the X chromosome and males have just one. Levels of gene expression usually reflect gene dosage: how many gene copies are present in an individual. Disrupting the balance of gene dosage between chromosomes typically has severe negative consequences. Understanding how and why mechanisms evolve to compensate for unbalanced gene dosage is an important goal both for medical and evolutionary research. This project focuses on moths and butterflies in which males have two copies of the sex-determining chromosome and females have just one. This project will systematically survey dosage compensation associated with sex-determining chromosomes in moths and butterflies. It will also test how factors like mutation rates and natural selection play a role in determining the evolution of balanced gene expression. The researchers will use the wide public appeal of moths and butterflies as a means to increase public engagement and knowledge about scientific research.

Theory predicts that a mechanism should exist for compensating X-linked gene expression between the sexes. Observations from different species reveal that often such mechanisms have evolved, but sometimes they do not. The reasons for this difference are not understood. Preliminary results suggest moths and butterflies harbor intriguing variation in the magnitude of dosage compensation. The research will combine transcriptome and genome sequencing to characterize patterns of dosage compensation in 10 phylogenetically diverse moth or butterfly species. RNA-sequencing will provide genome-wide estimates of gene expression to test for differences between sexes in sex-linked gene expression. This broad survey of dosage compensation will resolve questions regarding the presence of sex-determining chromosome dosage compensation in this prominent female-heterogametic taxon. Comparative genomic analyses and resequencing of targeted species will be used to infer patterns of male mutation bias and the relative effective population sizes of sex-determining chromosomes and other chromosomes. These population genetic factors are expected to correlate with the presence of dosage compensation and will be compared across species to test for such a relationship.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aim of this research was to apply genomic analyses to better understand the evolutionary and functional biology of sex chromosome dosage compensation (SCDC) in Lepidoptera (moths and butterflies). SCDC equalizes between sexes the gene expression on the sex chromosome, specifically on the X, where one sex has two copies (homogametic) but the other sex (heterogametic) has only one copy and a degenerate Y chromosome. Without SCDC, the single X chromosome of the heterogametic sex would be under-expressed relative to the homogametic sex due to unequal gene copy number between sexes. Theory suggests SCDC is an essential part of X chromosome evolution but previous results indicated it might be universally absent from female-heterogametic species. Nonetheless, preliminary results suggested that Lepidoptera, which are female-heterogametic, may be an exception. The research supported by this grant aimed to address patterns and mechanisms of SCDC in Lepidoptera. Our research primarily focused on two distantly related species: apple coddling moth (Cydia pomonella) and monarch butterfly (Danaus plexippus).

 

To begin with, we contributed substantially toward novel genomic resources for these species, yielding the first genome assembly for coddling moth and a dramatically improved assembly for monarch. Another important discovery we made was that the monarch butterfly carries a modified X chromosome that has fused with an autosome to generate a bipartite X chromosome with ancestral-X and neo-X strata. This was already known to be the case in coddling moth, but the fusion in monarch was independent, and thus gave novel opportunities to study how SCDC evolves in Lepidoptera after major genomic rearrangements. We analyzed SCDC in both species and found that the ancestral-X gene expression is balanced between sexes, but reduced relative to autosomes. This confirms that Lepidoptera are a notable and important exception to the emerging perspective that female-heterogametic species lack SCDC. It also indicates that for these genes, the theoretical prediction of compensatory up-regulation is incorrect.

 

For genes on the neo-X, the results were intriguingly different between the two species. In coddling moth, neo-X gene expression was comparable to ancestral-X genes, suggesting that there was a shared molecular mechanism regulating SCDC across the X chromosome. In monarchs, however, neo-X gene expression equaled autosomes, which is an unprecedented result for a couple reasons. It is the first example of compensatory up-regulation in any female-heterogametic taxon. Also, it is the first ever instance of distinct mechanisms of SCDC operating on the same chromosome.

 

To further investigate this mechanism, we employed Chromatin Immuno-Precipitation followed by sequencing (ChIP-seq) to assess the role of specific chemical modifications to DNA-binding proteins known to regulate gene expression. We found that at least one (H4K16 acetylation) differed between sexes and between ancestral-X versus neo-X in a manner consistent with the observed patterns of SCDC. This result further confirms the presence of distinct molecular mechanisms of SDCD distinguishing the two evolutionary strata on the monarch X chromosome, which is a previously unreported phenomenon in any species.

 

Taken together, the results from the research have substantially advanced our understanding of SCDC evolution and function in animals by confirming Lepidoptera as an exceptional lineage that does not readily conform to previous theoretical and empirical expectations, highlighting the need for further theoretical developments concerning genome function and evolution. By the conclusion of funding, four peer reviewed publications have been published, and two more are pending. More than a dozen or seminars have been presented on this work at scientific meetings and institutions. This funding has supported STEM training for two post-doctoral scholars, one PhD student, and five undergraduates. Lab members have participated in several STEM outreach activities, using butterflies as a vehicle to communicate science literacy to public audiences attending museum open houses and related events. Then availability of a complete genome sequence for coddling moth, which is a major invasive pest on apples and pears, will have broad benefits for future efforts at pest control.
